citeinfo.title: Gravity Data of Airborne Geophysical Surveys over the 2011 Mineral, Virginia, Earthquake Area
Airborne Geophysical Surveys over the 2011 Mineral, Virginia, Earthquake Area

descript.abstract: The 2011 moment magnitude (Mw) 5.8 central Virginia earthquake was felt by millions of people and caused significant damage in the eastern United States. As part of efforts to better understand the faults and geologic features associated with the earthquake, the U.S. Geological Survey commissioned airborne geophysical surveys over the epicentral area. The surveys were conducted from July 15, 2012 - July 25, 2012, by Sander Geophysics Limited. The area was flown along a draped surface with a nominal survey height above ground of 125 meters. The flight line spacing was 200 meters for traverse lines and 2000 meters for control lines. Here we present downloadable gravity data from those surveys as image (GeoTiff or kmz), grid (gxf) or flight line (csv) data.
descript.purpose: Dissemination of airborne geophysical survey data collected near the 2011 moment magnitude 5.8 Mineral, Virginia (Louisa County) earthquake and summary of research results.
descript.supplinf:
Initial interpretation of this dataset is provided by: Shah, A.K., Horton, J.W., Jr., Burton, W.C., Spears, D.B. and Gilmer, A.K. 2015, Subsurface geologic features of the 2011 central Virginia earthquakes revealed by airborne geophysics, in Horton, J.W., Jr., Chapman, M.C., and Green, R.A., eds., The 2011 Mineral, Virginia earthquake and its significance for seismic hazards in Eastern North America: Geological Society of America Special Paper 509. doi: 10.1130/2015.2509(17)
These data should be cited as follows: Shah, A., 2014, Airborne Geophysical Surveys over the 2011 Mineral, Virginia, Earthquake Area: U.S. Geological Survey Data Release, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F78K773V.

idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.

idinfo.datacred: The surveys were funded by the U.S. Geological Survey Earthquake Hazards and National Cooperative Geologic Mapping Programs, Natural Hazards and Core Science Systems Mission Areas, Northeast Regional Office, and Crustal Geophysics and Geochemistry Science Center. The data were collected and processed by Sander Geophysics Limited.

citeinfo.title: Subsurface geologic features of the 2011 central Virginia earthquakes revealed by airborne geophysics
The 2011 Mineral, Virginia earthquake and its significance for seismic hazards in Eastern North America

serinfo.sername: Geological Society of America Special Paper

attracc.attraccr: Gravity data consistency checks, calibrations and corrections include adjustments for aircraft accelerations, flying height, heading, pitch, roll, yaw, lag, Eötvös effect, and system noise. Control lines were used to level the dataset. A gravity tie was made using ground gravimeter measurements at a known reference point in Louisa County and at the parking spot of the survey aircraft. Details of data processing can be found in the Survey Technical Report by Sander Geophysics Limited at https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/53f5a9c9e4b09d12e0e86438

dataqual.logic: Tests for logical consistency between data attributes were performed where appropriate. Final data were also compared to previous regional datasets to check for consistency. Details of data processing can be found in the Survey Technical Report by Sander Geophysics Limited at https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/53f5a9c9e4b09d12e0e86438
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: Position and terrain clearance of the aircraft were determined by combining DGPS (differential global positioning system), radar, barometric, and laser altimetry measurements. Test flights over a known area were used for instrument calibration. Details can be found in the Survey Technical Report by Sander Geophysics Limited at https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/53f5a9c9e4b09d12e0e86438

vertacc.vertaccr: Position and terrain clearance of the aircraft were determined by combining DGPS (differential global positioning system), radar, barometric, and laser altimetry measurements. Test flights over a known area were used for instrument calibration. Details can be found in the Survey Technical Report by Sander Geophysics Limited at https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/53f5a9c9e4b09d12e0e86438

procstep.procdesc: The Survey Technical Report by Sander Geophysics Limited describing data collection and processing in detail can be found at https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/53f5a9c9e4b09d12e0e86438

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.

attr.attrdef: Flight line direction, degrees clockwise from North
GPS elevation, final (orthometric MSL - NAVD88 using GEOID09) (meters)
Levelled free air gravity, 15 s half-wavelength filter, 1,000 m half-wavelength grid filter (mGal)
Bouguer anomaly levelled, 15 s half-wavelength filter, 2.67 g/cm3 (mGal)
Bouguer anomaly levelled, 15 s half-wavelength filter, 2.60 g/cm3 (mGal)
Bouguer anomaly levelled, 15 s half-wavelength filter, 2.80 g/cm3 (mGal)

overview.eaover: Gravity measurements indicate subtle differences in the density of rocks in Earth's crust. The gravity anomaly can be used to indirectly map the distribution of different rock types. Gravity data includes the image (GeoTiff or kmz), grid (gxf) or flight line (csv) data.
overview.eadetcit: Shah, A., 2014. Airborne Geophysical Surveys over the 2011 Mineral, Virginia Earthquake Area. U.S. Geological Survey ScienceBase. Data files and documentation. doi: 10.5066/F78K773V. Access date.

digtinfo.formname: Image Files (GeoTiff and kmz) Raster Digital Data
Line Data (zipped csv file) Tabular Digital Data
digtinfo.formcont: See Entity and Attribute section (eainfo) for a full list of fields.

The grids provided here are: "FAA_1000_UTM18N_NAD83.gxf" : Gravitational Free-air anomaly (mGal) with a 1-km half-wavelength grid filter; "BA_267_1000_UTM18N_NAD83.gxf": the Bouguer anomaly (mGal) derived from the above free-air anomaly assuming a reference density of 2.67 g/m3.
Grids are in the ASCII grid exchange format (.gxf). Header information provides the grid dimensions, separation, coordinates and map projection, and z-value range information. The grid values follow.
